text:
Part 1
[2025/04/30 12:00:00 GMT+0000]
[00:00:00] Researcher 1: …then basically just dive in and…yes. 
[00:00:03] Participant 32: First of all, I'm Participant 32, hi. 
[00:00:10] Participant 31: I'm Participant 31. 
[00:00:10] Participant 33: Hi, Participant 31, hi, Participant 32, I'm Participant 33. 
[00:00:55] Participant 32: Nice. This is an inventory list and the letter. 
[00:00:56] Participant 31: Do you want to sit closer? 
[00:00:57] Participant 33: Can we write anything on that, or we can use our own paper? 
[00:00:58] Researcher 1: Oh, yes, you can write on that, [00:01:00] or there's also that. 
[00:01:00] Participant 33: Okay, I will take one, so from here, because I just read something which was the most relevant…
[00:01:24] Participant 32: Okay. 
[00:01:28] Participant 33: Do you [00:02:00] want to read [00:03:00] that also? [Inaudible] . We've [00:04:00] got only one copy of this. [Inaudible] .
[00:04:35] Participant 32: So, that first letter is from Carmen, who's collected all the evidence that we've got right now. 
[00:04:41] Participant 33: Yes, so Death at the Dive Bar, inventory, we've got 19 things, and let's see what I thought what is most important, we discuss that, and then Grey Investigations, I think the most important things [00:05:00] are in these two paragraphs, and then should we read this? Should I read it out? 
 "Dear Miss Grey, I'm writing because I think my boss was murdered, but I can't prove it on my own. I'm hoping someone at Grey Investigations can help me." So, it's only the introduction. 
 "Let me give you a little background, I learned everything I know," so I'm writing the first paragraph, introduction. 
 Now looking at the second… "I learned everything I know about bartending from my boss, Nick Webster. He taught me how to pull a perfect pint and coached me on 86ing rowdy patrons. He even helped me rearrange my work schedule so I could be [00:06:00] home more when my sister was sick last year, Nick was the best. Old Scratch Tavern isn't much to look at but it's one of those places that feels like home. That was all Nick." So, second, her emotional attachment and…
[00:06:17] Participant 32: Her relationship. 
[00:06:18] Participant 33: Her emotional attachment and she is somehow emotionally indebted to the victim, sort of the emotion is indebt…it's not love, but she feels indebted to him, second. Okay, third. 
 "I guess that's why it hit me so hard when Nick died in December. It was so sudden and so bizarre. The official story is that Nick was drunk and lost [00:07:00] his footing but too many strange things happened in the months leading up to his death for me to believe it was an accident." So, in the first paragraph, he's a nice man, he helps people, it was a nice tavern, so it is hard to believe [inaudible] , itself, third. Fourth…
 "The thing is Nick had been seeing the devil. For months, he had been telling anyone who would listen that there was someone or something lurking out in the woods behind the bar." So, now I'm writing from here the first he was telling about the woods behind the bar. How are you comfortable? Should I read one like this slowly? 
[00:07:59] Participant 32: [00:08:00] Yes, it's okay.
